title: Computationally Efficient Control Techniques for Optimizing Collaborative Tracking Tasks

context.prior_knowledge: Requirement of intermediate theoretical background and practical experience
context.additional_context: Learners are industry practitioners experienced in multi-subsystem collaborative tasks, aiming to bridge the gap between theoretical knowledge and practical application

learning_goals: Learners can explain the core principles of NOILC (Norm Optimal Iterative Learning Control) and its application cases in cooperative tracking tasks.
Learners can design optimization processes that reduce computational complexity using the non-lifting N-NOILC technique.
Learners can apply practical considerations and parameter-tuning methods when implementing ADMM (Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers)-based distributed solutions.

resources: MATLAB/Octave code templates for practical exercises

difficulty: Moderate - Standard complexity with some constraints
